column1: Between 20 September 2019 and 6 December 2019, will the closing price for Brent crude oil exceed $75.00, according to Bloomberg?
column6: ['Business']
The EIA lowered its forecasts for WTI and Brent early September. For 2020 as well.

Global trade and manufacturing demand will not rise in this period. Saudi arabia will keep supply high and Iran has taken its shot at “safely” disrupting supply. All oil producers need the money so they keep pumping. Big unknown remains Mideast conflict that drags others in.

Given current level of Brent crude price, percentage price change needs to be 16.8% over next 2 weeks for price to exceed US$75. Historically, such a 2-week price change happened once in 348 observations over the past 10 years. This gives a probability of 0.3%. Very closed to zero, but non-zero still. Sticking with 1%.
Fin.
https://www.cnbc.com/2019/11/20/oil-jumps-to-high-on-day-after-inventory-data-rising-tensions-in-saudi-arabia.html
(Passage of time update)
Between 20 September 2019 and 6 December 2019, will the closing price for Brent crude oil exceed $75.00, according to Bloomberg?

I’m at 1% only for black swan kind of event. From the Economist: “The latest oil outlook published by the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries does not make for cheery reading. The group lowered its forecast for oil demand as fears mount that a recession will reduce the need for it. That comes as OPEC has struggled to maintain a high oil price. In December last year OPEC and its allies, as well as Russia, agreed to cut output by 1.2m barrels a day to support the price of crude. Yet prices have slumped from almost $75 in April to around $60. A drone attack in September on Saudi Arabia’s biggest processing facility pushed prices up, but only temporarily. Little wonder that OPEC’s chief, Mohammad Barkindo, said in October that the club and its allies may consider deeper cuts to oil production when they meet in Vienna in December. After his comments, oil prices ticked up. However, much depends on the outcome of trade talks between China and America.”

Increasing from 2% to 5%, given recent news that Saudi Arabia's national oil company, Saudi Aramco, is in the process of launching its initial public offering [1,2, 3]. I think this slightly raises the possibility of another attack by Iran on Saudi Aramco's oil infrastructure - and another such attack would make it extremely likely that Brent crude will exceed $75.

I gave it just under a quarter a while back, interested to see how a revised amount will affect the score outcome. There really is not a lot of movement in the market at the moment, but it could be like those old western movies were someone says, I don't like it, its too darn quiet
Brent crude oil prices have been climbing. However, World economic growth has been declining.
(Passage of time update)
I think I might have over-priced the geo-political risk. Global growth seems to be the primary factor affecting crude prices. Adjusting down.

I reduced my forecast to 0% on the understanding that the question is asking for the "average" closing price between Sep 20 and Dec 6. If the question is asking for at any day before Dec 6, there is still a small chance (still <5%) that the price may exceed $75/bbl but only in response to another major geopolitical event.
A war would have to break out in Europe or the middle eastern countries for Brent to rise significantly
Checked my instincts using historic data and found about a 1% chance of this occurring.
14-21 days.
Very unlikely but not impossible - reaffirming 1%
The recent attack on Saudi Arabia still hasn't been avenged. Retribution is coming. During the impeachment hearings will be a good time.
Accounting for the prob of the price + likelihood of any unexpected disruption
It won't reach $75 in normal trading, but if there is a supply disruption it could easily reach $75, so it's just the probability of disruption.
Updating with current price and passing of time.
End of 2014 the price fell quickly from $113 down to $28 where it bottomed at the beginning of 2016 - since 2016 the price has only exceeded $75 a few times [all in 2018]
Lowering slightly for now. Generally need to see some better economic news, forecasts... https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-14/oil-holds-near-lows-as-u-s-china-trade-deal-hopes-evaporate
The glut of oil coming out of the US and the slowing world economy prevent oil from reaching such price levels.
Maybe there will be a war to drive it up, other than that prob not

There’s potential conflict with iran but rel with saudi is not strained. With the climate movements happening demand is going down, so if supply isnt affected will likely not go up. Looking at past years the trend seems to be decreasing prices towards the end of the years.
https://www.marketwatch.com/story/oil-prices-climb-though-us-crude-supplies-rise-a-4th-week-but-product-stocks-decline-2019-10-09
OPEC cut oil demand growth forecast once more, this time 40k b/d from September's forecast. Seems less likely that Brent crude oil will exceed $75.
VLC Carriers are earning 100,000 PER DAY will be watching for market choke points in energy transportations
Updating as prices continue to fall. The global growth narrative seems to be over-shadowing geo-political tensions
Oil price volatility is very high.
PMI falling, EIA and similar agencies has been revising their demand estimates down by approximately 30% i.e. weak demand. My 5% estimate, is weighted with the crowd.
Revised forecast after recent reports and Brent crude price
Only a Local war will create this level of oil price.
global growth concerns are driving oil prices more than conflict and the markets seem to be ignoring any geo-political risk premium in the Middle East (see link for ICE Dec futures below).
Global economic slowdown is starting to kick in while Russia and Saudis will continue to pump oil into the market. The outlook for Brent is not bullish for the remainder of this year.
14-21 days.

Over the past 5 years, there has only been <45 days in which Brent crude oil registered a price above $75. Due to the uncertainty of global economic growth and barring any significant terrorist attacks, demand is unlikely to spike.

Normally I would have expected the Saud Refinery attack to have driven up the price about ten bucks. However the rally was two days and volatility has returned to lows. EIA says that U.S. exports of refined goods is way up - and that is after losing capacity in the Philadelphia fire. That was at the largst refinery in the nation and its still not repaired. The Sauds use a Modular plug in system for a robust repairable pipe works. HOWEVER the Red Chinese have been tying up every tanker charter it can find and anchoring them offshore as floating storage and causing tanker rates to soar, so there may be additional volitility if China tries to corner the energy transportation market.
1. Recalculating the odds, given crude oil is now at US$60.78. This implies 21% price increase required, which has a probability of 1.4%. 2. US data worsen.
Lowering for now as reports claim Saudis have essentially restored damaged oil production + demand-related concerns as well.
Even the Saudi outage of nearly 5-6 MBD didn't cause a spike above $75. Also, futures markets have been trading at below $60 for Dec19.
Lowering forecast from 10 to 5 due to falling oil prices over the past two weeks. The percentage increase in price required to reach 75% is now much higher.
Depends on what transpires between Iran and Saudi Arabia between now and then.
Adjusting down based on recent market data for global growth
Briefly looking at 5.5 years of price data
Loose estimate from eyeballing base rate over 5 years.
Revising downward for now, in light of update on this week's oil prices: https://www.marketwatch.com/story/oil-lower-after-saudi-arabia-reportedly-moves-to-impose-partial-yemen-cease-fire-2019-09-27

Oil price has only been above 75 for 1 in the last 5 years, with a bump in 2018 that didn't quite get there. Base chance of 20% then. Countries producing oil have potential to produce more, and are motivated to manage price. Significant attack in Saudi Arabia failed to drive the price up to 75, and prices usually cheaper in winter. Therefore modified down to 12% - only likely in the event of a very significant crisis in one country.

Tensions are increasing, Trump is getting more unstable, and there will continue to be tension in the Gulf. Iran can take out Saudi oil production. As pressure on Iran increases, pressures on Saudi oil production from Iran will increase. Trump is getting more vulnerable, opening a way for Iran to extract concessions from Trump in response to Iranian pressure.

Slight adjustment downward for now, attempting to balance reported Saudi oil infrastructure rebuilding concerns (ref.: https://www.wsj.com/articles/aramcos-repairs-could-take-months-longer-than-company-anticipates-contractors-say-11569180194), with reported "..expectations of lower demand due to a weakening global economy..". (Ref.: https://www.fxempire.com/forecasts/article/oil-price-fundamental-daily-forecast-demand-concerns-are-back-api-report-on-tap-602016)
Adjusting down

I'm seeing upward pressure from the sanctions on carriers trading in snctioned oil with China and the growing fleet of tanker as storage preparing for the Oct 1st change in fuel standards for shipping.
Conflicts with Iran, its proxies and Saudi Arabia will continue as long as Iran is being squeezed financially

The price of crude rising above $75 relies on a conflict between Saudi Arabia and Iran. Unlikely due to the economic impact on Saudi Arabia a conflict will have due to the control Iran has over the strait of Hormuz.

Taking a view of the demand side factors first - probability of global recession is increasing, some reports suggest it is the highest its been since 2009, beating the previous "recession likelihood" peaks in 2011 and 2012. This implies lower overall global demand for energy consumption. Additionally, environmental concerns seem to be gaining traction (while this will not be a large factor, the direction of travel could weigh on oil price sentiment).
Saudi production issues generally related to refined products. Attacks do not appear to have created a shortage of crude, although the price may fall, in part due to reduction in refining capacity.

Predictions for Saudi Arabia and Iran conflict suggest that there is low probability of another attack on Saudi Arabian Oil production. Likewise the release of the British oil tanker makes it seem highly probable that tensions in the Middle East will diffuse. Current oil prices are at $62.42 and future contracts are trading at similar prices for two and three months out, which suggest that the market is not expect the price of oil to rise rapidly. [1] Saudi Arabian production seems to have gotten back to it's usual levels pretty quickly. So, it seems at this point that a rapid rise in price would be an unlikely occurrence.
**I am writing this after the market close on Wednesday, September 25. Brent closed today at $62.42.**

Brent oil price has not surpassed $75 once this year in 2019, In 2018 Brent oil priced dropped in Q4 and the peak price from the Saudi oil attack did not break $70. I expect close 0% with a margin of 3% for outlying factors.
Shortages are being reported globally, whether or not its propaganda doesn't matter in the short term. Threat of Iranian war is significant. Fracking issues from Dems.
Leading indicator shows crude oil bid into December. Brent has no major resistance up to $80-90.
The price didn't even hit $70 right after the Iranian attack. Unless there is another attack or a war in the area, I don't see how prices hit $75.
Adjusting from 22% on arguments here (which I had factored in to some extent already) https://www.cnbc.com/2019/09/23/rusty-braziel-to-jim-cramer-sharp-sustained-oil-price-hikes-unlikely.html

in the past 4 years the Q4 Brent rate has declined as often as it has increased. Of the 2 years that it increased only 1 instance was above the 15% needed to cross the $75 threshold in Q4, so the base rate for me is 25%. I'm not certain of any inclination of Iran towards escalation/deescalation so I will not adjust the base (yet) for this. Saudi Arabia has a strong disincentive to further escalation due to Aramco IPO in the near future (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-aramco-ipo-timing/saudi-aramco-ipo-unlikely-to-happen-this-year-after-oil-attacks-sources-idUSKBN1W91DA). The IPO is important for many domestic stability reasons. There are also significant reserves elsewhere globally and storage is close to capacity, so other market instability seems less worrisome. https://foreignpolicy.com/2019/09/18/the-real-reason-trump-wont-attack-iran-saudi/
From the demand side, 1% as the World is impacted by multiple economic tensions. No increase in demand is probable.
The key factor here will be if Saudi Arabia (backed by the USA) goes to war with Iran. this will drive the prices up.
Global economic weakness and falling GDP projections against Middle East tensions. Economic weakness seems more certain in the short term.

Instead of counting number of days prices had exceeded US$75, I look at the price increase that would need to bring price to US$75. The price I'm looking at now is US$64.27. That means an increase of 15.4% is required over the next 73 days, or 10.4 weeks.

The U.S. announced by Trump is "Locked and loaded indicating that we're in the game and that there's more to come. Next, SA released reserves to stabilize the price, US added sanctions on Iran (who denies involvement.) Germany, France, and UK join US to blame Iran for attacks on SA oil fields. Iran says British tanker free to leave after 2 months detention and ahead of the U.N. summit. US and Europe now talking about negotiating a new Iran nuclear agreement. Time can march slowly without a need for agression in such a scenario and the question ends in a couple of months. Don't see that happening in the time frame especially as Iran made a concessionary move by releasing that UK tanker.

I am dramatically revising down to 60% to 85%, due to two key developments: 1) The Brent crude oil price did not jump up in world markets today as I thought they might, given a popular WSJ over the weekend that reported more Iranian attacks on SA are likely. This reporting apparently had little to no effect on world markets. 2) Iran just took a step to ease tensions by releasing a British-flagged tanker.
Decreasing on the argument that as others have pointed out the large shale capacity in the US places downward pressure on the price as producers can quickly ramp up once the price becomes high.
To dangerous for another disruption so soon. Lots of oil and production capacity.

Adjusting down slightly based on some research: https://www.google.com/amp/s/oilprice.com/Energy/Crude-Oil/The-Myth-Of-Cheap-Shale-Oil.amp.html https://www.investopedia.com/articles/active-trading/051215/cost-shale-oil-versus-conventional-oil.asp

Update: "Houthi militants in Yemen have warned foreign diplomats that Iran is preparing a follow-up strike to the missile and drone attack that crippled Saudi Arabia’s oil industry a week ago, people familiar with the matter said." [1]

Seventy Dollars is seen as a limit, anything trading over that would be flagged, in the good ole days ppl could ride a trend, not so much now. Would think that there will be a good effort to keep prices as stable as possible, but you have to factor in any forms of external drive

Base rate: Looking at data in the five years since the steep fall of oil prices in 2014 due to slowing economic growth in the BRIC countries, the fracking boom in North America, and a failure by OPEC to enact production cuts [1]. All of these factors have relatively constant since then, which is why oil prices have been historically low. In the past 5 years (~1825 days), oil prices have exceeded $75 for ~187 days, which is ~10% of the days of this 5-year time period [2]. In the past 1 year (~365 days), oil prices have exceeded $75 for ~45 days, which is ~12% of the days of this 1-year time period.

9/20/19 analysis article excerpt: "Friday’s price action suggests traders are building in a risk premium. This is because the Saudis are drawing on inventory, repairs are still taking place and the threat of further attacks on their oil production facilities have not been contained or eliminated. Before the market can really become stable, Saudi inventories are going to have to return to pre-attack levels, the damaged facilities are going to have to be repaired and working at full capacity and further threats will have to be prevented...." (Source link: https://finance.yahoo.com/news/oil-price-fundamental-daily-forecast-123857287.html. Also ref.: https://www.dailyfx.com/forex/market_alert/2019/09/17/Crude-Oil-Price-Outlook-Oil-Backwardation-Highest-in-6-Years-.html)
~~~ Outside View ~~~

Geo-political risks are heightened and the recent supply shock pushed the markets to begin pricing it in. That being said, demand is lower in the winter months which could cause prices to fall. EIA forecast is for $61.
